data.title: Added mipmap generation for DirectX render targets

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
Mipmaps for render targets are created in GraphicsDevice.PlatformResolveRenderTargets (similar to the already functioning mipmap generation in the OpenGL code). 

I have added a unit test which is currently set to Ignore because:
In my tests generated mipmaps are different in XNA and MonoGame. The XNA mipmaps look wrong, as if created with point sampling!? MonoGame mipmaps look correct. 
Tested mipmaps in DirectX/OpenGL and Windows/MacOS are identical but only if the texture size is a power of two. 

Related issues:
- Rendertargets are lacking mipmapping functionality #1001

data.title: Added OcclusionQuery implementation for DirectX.
data.body:
This PR splits the OcclusionQuery.cs into OcclusionQuery._Platform_.cs files and adds an implementation for DirectX.

The PR also adds unit tests. One test uses the SpriteBatch. It should currently fail because of the SpriteBatch z value bug. It should work after following PR is merged:
- Fix: SpriteBatch writes wrong z value. #4184

Previously, OcclusionQuery.cs was excluded from iOS, Android and Ouya builds. I have tested the occlusion query on iOS and Android, and the query works if the device supports OpenGL ES 3.0. I have not tested on devices without ES 3.0 support - therefore, the OcclusionQuery files are still excluded on iOS, Android and Ouya.

This PR should also fix a bug in the OpenGL implementation: 
The pixel count was retrieved with `QueryResultAvailable` (which returns only true/false) instead of `QueryResult`. (The MonoMac code path did not have this problem.)

Related issues: 
- Missing OcclusionQuery class from Graphics namespace #414
- DirectX and OcclusionQuery #4033

data.title: Unable to use 3D models in a Custom Content reader, Missing MaterialContentReader
data.body:
In testing this weekend, i spun up the old XNA CustomModel sample project.
This takes a basic FBX model, extracts the underlying vertex data so it can be worked on inside a Gaming project.

However, when you try this in a MonoGame solution, the following error is generated:
Could not find ContentTypeReader Type. Please ensure the name of the Assembly that contains the Type matches the assembly in the full type name: Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ReflectiveReader`1[[Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.Graphics.MaterialContent, MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline, Version=3.5.0.652, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null]] (Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ReflectiveReader`1[[Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.Graphics.MaterialContent, MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline]])

So it looks like MG is missing a Content Pipeline reader for MaterialContent.

data.title: Content pipeline showing wrong location and root node name (Windows)
data.body:
When I create a new monogame project and open the MGCB file, the location of the MGCB file shown in the GUI is wrong (see attached image). The actual location of the file is what it should be, not the one shown in the pipeline GUI.

The root node is also shown with the name "CONTEN~1" instead of "Content", which I guess is related to the location name error.

I'm using swedish as my Windows language.

![pipeline location](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12908966/10573848/b47174d8-7652-11e5-8d85-a96f3fe58b3d.png)

data.title: GameHasControl always returns true on iOS regardless of background music.
data.body:
To reproduce:
1. Create a MonoGame iOS project
2. Open Spotify
3. Begin playing music on spotify
4. Run the game
5. Check `Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Media.MediaPlayer.GameHasControl`

Expected: `Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Media.MediaPlayer.GameHasControl` should return false if background music is playing
Actual results: `Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Media.MediaPlayer.GameHasControl` returns true regardless of whether background music is playing.

data.title: Fix: SpriteBatch writes wrong z value.
data.body:
The default transformation matrix of the SpriteBatch creates wrong z values. This is only a problem if sprites are rendered with enabled depth test. 
If we switch the near and far plane of the transformation matrix, we get the same results as XNA.

data.title: Matrix.Invert(Matrix matrix) fix
data.body: I had a weird bug with Xamarin.iOS while Debug build was running fine, but Release build had a corrupted view matrix.

data.title: Fix: VertexStride not set in VertexContent if model contains only POSITION vertex channel.
Fix for WP81 template: GamePage is not calling InitializeComponent
data.body:
When InitializeComponent() is not called, the template can still be used to create a running game but InputDialog.ResizeLayoutRoot() will throw a NullReferenceException (because the Grid in the GamePage cannot be found).

The other templates do not have this problem.

- /Installers/Linux/monogame-sdk.deb
- /Installers/Linux/monogame-sdk.run

You could also connect it to development build for Linux on the website, .deb is Ubuntu installer and .run is the installer for other Linux distros.

data.title: [WIP] Linux Installer Update { MonoGame.Content.Builder.targets, Description fix, Mac building }
System.DllNotFoundException: Unable to load DLL Mfplat.dll
data.body:
Hello,

This is not a MonoGame issue but a system requirement for Windows (DirectX) projects I'd like to document.

When trying to play a `Song` through `MediaPlayer`, it may happen that you or your players run into a `System.DllNotFoundException` raised by `SharpDX.MediaFoundation.MediaFactory.Startup` and concerning the Mfplat.dll

This is due to the fact that the running operating system is a so called "Windows N" or "KN". The "N" means that the Windows version doesn't have Windows Media Player installed and also lack a few music playback related DLL's.
These versions of Windows are not very common and are most probably only found in some professional environments and a few countries where anti-competitive policies are enforced regarding Windows Media Player.

To resolve this problem, users have to install the **Media Feature Pack** of the corresponding Windows version:
- Windows 7 N Download: http://www.microsoft.com/en-US/download/details.aspx?id=16546
- Windows 8 N Download: http://www.microsoft.com/en-US/download/details.aspx?id=30685
- Windows 8.1 N Download: http://www.microsoft.com/en-US/download/details.aspx?id=40744
- Windows 10 N Download: https://www.microsoft.com/en-US/download/details.aspx?id=48231

Windows Vista & XP (which don't have this feature pack) users should be invited to install **Windows Media Player**:
- http://www.microsoft.com/en-US/download/windows-media-player-details.aspx?id=8163

If you are distributing a Windows project, it is advised to warn your players about this (in addition to DirectX June 2010 redist & .Net 4.0 requirements). Please be aware that redistributing these feature packs is not allowed by their EULA. A good practice would be to detect the presence of Mfplat.dll and invite users to install this pack.

If I have time, I'll update the MonoGame documention with a "how to distribute your project" page for every target platforms and how to cleanly package them.

EDIT: to detect if the media feature are installed, you can check if the registry value `IsInstalled` is set to 1 for the key `HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Active Setup\Installed Components\{6BF52A52-394A-11d3-B153-00C04F79FAA6}`

Sample code (to place at the beginning of your main, for example):

```
object legacyWMPCheck = Microsoft.Win32.Registry.GetValue(@"HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Active Setup\Installed Components\{22d6f312-b0f6-11d0-94ab-0080c74c7e95}", "IsInstalled", null);
            if (legacyWMPCheck == null || legacyWMPCheck.ToString() != "1")
            {
                MessageBox.Show("It appears that you don't have Windows Media Player installed. This game needs system features bound to Windows Media Player. Please install the Media Feature Pack corresponding to your Windows version to run this game:"
                    + Environment.NewLine
                    + Environment.NewLine
                    + "Windows 7: http://www.microsoft.com/en-US/download/details.aspx?id=16546"
                    + Environment.NewLine
                    + Environment.NewLine
                    + "Windows 8: http://www.microsoft.com/en-US/download/details.aspx?id=30685"
                    + Environment.NewLine
                    + Environment.NewLine
                    + "Windows 8.1: http://www.microsoft.com/en-US/download/details.aspx?id=40744"
                    + Environment.NewLine
                    + Environment.NewLine
                    + "Windows 10: https://www.microsoft.com/en-US/download/details.aspx?id=48231"
                    + Environment.NewLine
                    + Environment.NewLine
                    + "Windows Vista & XP: http://www.microsoft.com/en-US/download/windows-media-player-details.aspx?id=8163",
                    "Missing Windows Media Player", MessageBoxButtons.OK, MessageBoxIcon.Error);

                return;
            }
```

data.title: Added missing method in Gamepad.UWP.cs
Latest commit has missing implementation for GamePad.UWP.PlatformGetMaxIndex()
data.body: The most recently made commit by @tomspilman introduces an issue whereby the implementation for PlatformGetMaxIndex() is missing from the UWP partial class implementation of GamePad. Leads to compilation errors.

data.title: Fixed incorrect color serialization using intermediate serializer.
data.body: Fix for color serialization when using the intermediate serializer. (issue #4169 )

data.title: SpriteBatcher item pool
data.body:
1) Initialize the pool with new 'SpriteBatchItem' instances in the
constructor. Avoid allocation/GC during gameplay.
2) Remove line '_freeBatchItemQueue.Enqueue(item)' from the inner loop.
Instead of a Queue we pool items in a List<> and keep an index to the
next free item. After the loop we set the index to 0 to return all the
items to the pool.

|  | XNA | MG DX | MG GL |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| _Original_ Average Draw(ms): | 2,46571 | 1,27025 | 1,51469 |
| _this PR_ Average Draw(ms): | N/A | 1,21511 | 1,45861 |
| Diff (%) | N/A | 95.7% | 96.3% |

using https://github.com/danzel/DrawTextTest

data.title: Fixed clipping issue when using circular dead zone
data.body:
This fixes the circular dead zone clipping issue described in issue #4170.

I'll also submit a separate PR to remove the superfluous `GamePadThumbSticks.Gate` property once this has been merged.

data.title: Thumbstick inputs being clipped when using circular deadzone
data.body:
I've been working on improving and fine-tuning controller input for my game recently, and I've noticed when using the circular deadzone setting that the thumbsticks feel a bit too touchy.

After doing some investigation, I found that the method being used in MonoGame seems to be incorrect. Here is a graph showing what it's currently doing. The colours represent the resulting thumbstick vector length: Blue = 0 (i.e. the deadzone), Green = Normal range, Yellow = 1 (i.e. full movement)
![circular_deadzone_with_circular_gate](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5249498/10328138/1e79c7c8-6ce3-11e5-980a-e3cbdbe7ccd6.png)
So you can see from the big thick yellow area that the values are being clipped. This results in a halfway movement of the thumbstick being equivalent to a full movement. This is not what I'd expect. And looking at Shawn Hargreaves blog article on this subject (http://blogs.msdn.com/b/shawnhar/archive/2007/03/28/gamepads-suck.aspx), the graphs he provided don't seem to show any clipping being done like this. So I'm assuming this behaviour is actually incorrect.

This is my expectation of what the graph should actually look like (which is in line with Shawn Hargreaves graph):
![new_method_with_circular_gate](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5249498/10328141/24f2b6c8-6ce3-11e5-8b45-1e5d9ba278af.png)

Unless anyone has reason to believe I'm wrong about this, I'm planning to submit a PR soon which corrects this.

Also on a related note - While looking into this, I came across the GamePadThumbSticks.Gate property. I can't seem to find this in XNA, so I assume it's been added to MonoGame for some reason? I'm not sure exactly why this setting is needed, but the default for it is GateType.Round (which normalises the thumbstick vector if it's length is greater than 1). So if I set it to GateType.None, then the above graph now looks like this:
![circular_deadzone_with_no_gate](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5249498/10328143/2b1bbc48-6ce3-11e5-983a-b8c8b9039419.png)
Red means that the vector length exceeds the expected maximum of 1. So basically GateType.Round was hiding these out of range values coming from the circular deadzone function.

Does anyone know why this Gate property was added to MonoGame? It seems unnecessary as the deadzone setting could be controlling this (ie. GamePadDeadZone.IndependentAxes => GateType.Square,  GamePadDeadZone.Circular => GateType.Round, GamePadDeadZone.None => GateType.None). I have a funny feeling that it might have been added to correct these out of range values, so it might be unnecessary if this was the reason.

data.title: SoundEffect is playing garbage instead of WAV loaded via FromStream
data.body:
I'm playing several SoundEffects through SoundEffect.Play. They all come out sounding like:
- Garbage
- The same garbage regardless of what sound is actually played
- The same duration regardless of the duration of the actual sound

I'm loading the sounds with `SoundEffect.FromStream(<wav stream>)`. Here's one of the wavs that demonstrates the issue:

https://sr.ht/18MH.wav

data.title: Fix ContentExtensions.GetAllProperties for Win10 when Native toolchain enabled
data.body:
I  found that loading Xml from content files works incorrect for Win10 in release mode (or to be more precise when native toolchain is enabled).
It looks like `ContentExtensions.GetAllProperties` always return empty array due to condition `(p.GetMethod == p.GetMethod.GetRuntimeBaseDefinition())` (which is true without native toolchain, and false with) .
I am not sure what exactly should check this code, but in my case it works as expected without it.

data.title: Moving content in the pipeline tool
data.body: Right now its not possible to move content in the pipeline tool (at least not on Windows), drag-and-drop moving of content would be a great feature.

data.title: Fix for project.json
data.body: Rename project.json to MonoGame.Framework.WindowsUAP.project.json so it only builds with the UAP project (requires NuGet 3.2 and Tools for Universal apps v1.1)

data.title: Sound instance pool optimization to look for matching format in the pool
data.body:
This is a follow up to #4155 where @tomspilman suggested this optimization.

It checks if there is any `SoundEffectInstance` with the same format of the given `SoundEffect` in the pool to efficiently re-use instances.
This only impacts XAudio for now.

It would be cool to document this in the documentation to warn that using too many different `SoundEffect` formats may impact performance (or the opposite, that using the same format for all sounds is best).

In our project, all sounds have the same format, hence it would be nice to test this PR against more varied projects.

data.title: SpriteBatch not rendering
data.body:
## Main issue

I've been working on a 2D game where you can build, but I am having issues working with cursors, I'm attempting to use a SpriteBatch cursor, but it isn't drawing at all, The blocks draw fine, but the cursor still refuses to draw. 
## Code

I have everything defined, Here is the block that has issues though

``` c#
spriteBatch.Draw(cursor, cursorPos, Color.Transparent);
```

Nothing is rendering here,
## Edits

I changed the code from the old one in Code, to

``` c#
spriteBatch.Draw(cursor, cursorPos, Color.WhiteSmoke);
```

It draws in the topleft corner, but still isn't drawing where I want it to.
